item.title: 6th ATX Diversity Hackathon Rules and Judging criteria
item.description: Prize Categories There are the five categories for prizes. All projects are automatically entered into all categories. Deep learning - Sponsored by Bestow UI/UX - Sponsored by The Zebra Social impact - Sponsored by Athena Health Technical stack - Sponsored by Athena Health Overall - Sponsored by Athena Health Assembling Your Team The max team size is 5 people. You can organize your own team. If you are looking for projects or teammates, please sign up for slack here and use the #pitch channel.

item.title: 6th ATX Diversity Hackathon Workshop Schedule
item.description: FRIDAY, September 18 12:00 - 1:00 PM: How to Not Die Broke: Investing Strategies You Need to Know Presenter: Kara Perez [twitter instagram] 1:00 - 2:00 PM: Communicating with Diagrams: A designer’s tips for creating engineering diagrams that clearly & efficiently convey their intended message Presenter: Sara Wells Bring a diagram you’d like to make more clear, or just any diagram you’re familiar with. Or if you prefer, just join and listen!

item.title: Women Who Code Austin 6th Annual Diversity Hackathon Sign up
item.description: Join Women Who Code Austin (ATX) for our 6th annual Diversity Hackathon, sponsored by Google Fiber, AthenaHealth, Bestow and the Zebra. This is a virtual hackathon, with online workshops. When: Fri, Sep 18, 2020, 9:00 AM – Sun, Sep 20, 2020, 5:00 PM CDT Registration: sign up here This hackathon is a celebration of diversity. Anyone who supports diversity is welcome — no matter your level of technical knowledge. We are providing a virtual space for people of all backgrounds who want to start building their tech portfolio or finish up a tech project while learning new skills.

item.title: About Women Who Code ATX
item.description: Women Who Code started as a community group in 2011 when a handful of technologists decided they wanted to change the industry experience for women engineers. Since then, it has become a global non-profit organization and the world’s largest and most active community dedicated to inspiring women to excel in technology careers. One city at a time, Women Who Code spread around the world, reaching more than 20 countries. The Austin Network started with a Meetup hosted by a recent bootcamp graduate and has grown into a vibrant community with members in all phases of their technical careers.

item.title: Code of Conduct for Virtual Hackathon
item.description: Women Who Code (WWCode) is dedicated to providing an empowering experience for everyone who participates in or supports our community. Our events are intended to inspire women to excel in technology careers, and anyone who is there for this purpose is welcome. Because we value the safety and security of our members and strive to have an inclusive community, we do not tolerate harassment of members or event participants in any form.
